results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

results.title: Spotlights: David Gulpilil
results.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Gulpilil
constellations_primary.description: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Gulpilil was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.description: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).
description_for_label: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).

results.title: Reel to Reel Tape Recorder
results.brief_description: Used as the news gathering sound recorder at channel 7 sydney in the 1960s and early 1970s when external news footage was shot on 16mm reversal film. When it was upgraded with a Nagra 4.2 it became the in-house 1/4 inch transfer machine until Betacam became the dominant technology in the 1980s.
results.description: Used as the news gathering sound recorder at channel 7 sydney in the 1960s and early 1970s when external news footage was shot on 16mm reversal film. When it was upgraded with a Nagra 4.2 it became the in-house 1/4 inch transfer machine until Betacam became the dominant technology in the 1980s.

When it was upgraded with a Nagra 4.2 it became the in-house 1/4 inch transfer machine until Betacam became the dominant technology in the 1980s.

results.title: Make-up box complete with make up
results.brief_description:
Make-up box complete with make up from make up artist Paul Blackwell, owned by his widow Lee-Anne Donnolley
Note: Edie Kurzer has taken items out of the box and displayed them in the cabinet. I have tried to inventory them and assocatiate items back to the loaned make up case where possible (limited documentation photographs). Parts added are definitely from the case however other items on display may be originally from this object.
results.description: Make-up box complete with make-up from make-up artist Paul Blackwell, owned by his widow Lee-Anne Donnolley.

results.title: Magic Lantern Set Effects Slide [La Tarte aux Oiseaux - The Bird Pie]
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. A man smiles holding a large pie - by sliding the effects slide, a three birds fly out of the pie and his smile turns in to a frown. Black tape has been adhered to the edge of the sliding section.
results.title_for_label: Magic Lantern Set Effects Slide [La Tarte aux Oiseaux - The Bird Pie]

results.title: Magic Lantern Set Effects Slide [Les Jouers de Cartes - The Card Players]
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern set effects slipping slide in wooden frame [Les Jouers de Cartes - the Card Players]. By sliding the effects slide, two card players’ heads turn in to a chicken (left) and a dog (right).
results.title_for_label: Magic Lantern Set Effects Slide [Les Jouers de Cartes - The Card Players]

results.title: Magic Lantern Slipping Slide [Le Nez d'Arlequin - The Harlequin's Nose]
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern slipping slide ‘Le Nez d’Arlequin’ -‘ The Harlequin’s Nose’ or ‘Punch with Long Nose’ with wooden frame. Manufactured by E.Mazo, Paris. By moving the slipping slide, a harlequin’s nose grows longer and three small children appear on the tip. The words ‘Punch’s Long Nose’ is etched vertically in to the glass plate.
